citations.narrative:
A current record of guinea pigs was not available for review during this inspection. A total of 418 adult guinea pigs,
weanlings, and newborns were counted during this inspection. There were no inventory records kept or maintained since
the previous inspection report. Failure to maintain these records makes it difficult to assess the health of the caviary by
identifying animal losses by decreased number of guinea pig born, raised, or died. The licensee must maintain records
containing the required information for animals which disclose the number of guinea pigs held, owned, acquired or
disposed of including births and deaths. Remains uncorrected.

Storage. There is an open bag of guinea pig feed on a pallet with a large hole in the bottom corner of the bag. Spilled feed
is present on and under the pallet along with guinea pig droppings scattered on the floor. Failure to protect food and
bedding supplies adequately can result in spoilage, deterioration, and/or contamination. Open bags of feed must be
stored in containers with lids or covers to protect supplies from spoilage, deterioration, or contamination. Remains
uncorrected.

Feeding. The self-feeders on the sides of the guinea pig enclosures were covered with dust, dirt, and cobwebs. Failure to
keep self-feeders clean can result in deterioration or contamination of the feed which can affect the health of the guinea
pigs. All self-feeders must be kept clean, and self-feeders must be sanitized at least once 2 weeks. Remains uncorrected.

There are accumulations of brown debris inside the PVC drainpipes around the automatic water nipples. Dirt and debris
around the water nipples can expose the guinea pigs to potential infections with bacterial, fungi, and parasites. Water
receptacles such as automatic water lines must be sanitized when dirty, and at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by June
13, 2023.

There are accumulations of dust, dirt, debris, and cobwebs on the sides of guinea pig enclosures, racks, walls, ceiling,
window sills, self-feeders, and water drainpipes. Spilled feed is present on the floor of the animal room by the food
storage pallet. Guinea pig droppings are present along walls, under animal racks, and around and under the food storage
pallet. Animal facilities must be kept clean and in good repair to protect the health of the guinea pigs. Correct by ensuring
the premises are kept clean, including: removing accumulations of dust, dirt, cobwebs, spilled feed, guinea pig droppings,
and debris from surfaces and the floor of the animal room; and maintaining a level of general cleanliness to support good
animal husbandry and health. Remains uncorrected.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
A current record of guinea pigs was not available for review during this inspection. A total of 418 adult guinea pigs, 
weanlings, and newborns were counted during this inspection. There were no inventory records kept or maintained since 
the previous inspection report. Failure to maintain these records makes it difficult to assess the health of the caviary by 
identifying animal losses by decreased number of guinea pig born, raised, or died. The licensee must maintain records 
containing the required information for animals which disclose the number of guinea pigs held, owned, acquired or 
disposed of including births and deaths. Remains uncorrected. 
3.25(c)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
Storage. There is an open bag of guinea pig feed on a pallet with a large hole in the bottom corner of the bag. Spilled feed 
is present on and under the pallet along with guinea pig droppings scattered on the floor. Failure to protect food and 
bedding supplies adequately can result in spoilage, deterioration, and/or contamination. Open bags of feed must be 
stored in containers with lids or covers to protect supplies from spoilage, deterioration, or contamination. Remains 
uncorrected. 
3.29(d)  Repeat
   
Feeding. 
Feeding. The self-feeders on the sides of the guinea pig enclosures were covered with dust, dirt, and cobwebs. Failure to 
keep self-feeders clean can result in deterioration or contamination of the feed which can affect the health of the guinea 
pigs. All self-feeders must be kept clean, and self-feeders must be sanitized at least once 2 weeks. Remains uncorrected. 
3.30 
   
Watering. 
There are accumulations of brown debris inside the PVC drainpipes around the automatic water nipples. Dirt and debris 
around the water nipples can expose the guinea pigs to potential infections with bacterial, fungi, and parasites. Water 
receptacles such as automatic water lines must be sanitized when dirty, and at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by June 
13, 2023.

3.31(b)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
There are accumulations of dust, dirt, debris, and cobwebs on the sides of guinea pig enclosures, racks, walls, ceiling, 
window sills, self-feeders, and water drainpipes. Spilled feed is present on the floor of the animal room by the food 
storage pallet. Guinea pig droppings are present along walls, under animal racks, and around and under the food storage 
pallet. Animal facilities must be kept clean and in good repair to protect the health of the guinea pigs. Correct by ensuring 
the premises are kept clean, including: removing accumulations of dust, dirt, cobwebs, spilled feed, guinea pig droppings, 
and debris from surfaces and the floor of the animal room; and maintaining a level of general cleanliness to support good 
animal husbandry and health. Remains uncorrected. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
